description: Possibly from Middle English fit (“an adversary of equal power”).

entries.meaning: Suitable, proper.
examples: You have nothing to say about it. I'll do exactly as I see fit.

entries.meaning: Adapted to a purpose or environment.
examples: survival of the fittest

entries.meaning: In good shape; physically well.
examples: You don't have to be a good climber for Kilimanjaro, but you do have to be fit.

entries.meaning: (Britain, informal, chiefly slang) Sexually attractive; good-looking; fanciable.
examples: I think the girl working in the office is fit.

entries.meaning: Prepared; ready.
examples: So fit to shoot, she singled forth among her foes who first her quarry's strength should feel.

entries.meaning: The degree to which something fits.
examples: This shirt is a bad fit.
Since he put on weight, his jeans have been a tight fit.

entries.meaning: Conformity of elements one to another.
examples: It's hard to get a good fit using second-hand parts.

entries.meaning: The part of an object upon which anything fits tightly.
(advertising) Measure of how well a particular commercial execution captures the character or values of a brand.
examples: The Wonder Bread advertising research results showed the “White Picket Fence” commercial had strong fit ratings.

entries.meaning: (statistics) Goodness of fit.
(bridge) The quality of a partnership's combined holding of cards in a suit, particularly of trump.
examples: During the auction, it is often a partnership's goal to find an eight-card major suit fit.

verbs.description: fit (third-person singular simple present fits, present participle fitting, simple past and past participle fitted or fit)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be suitable for.
examples: It fits the purpose.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have sufficient space available at some location to be able to be there.
examples: Ten clowns fit in the car, but not a hundred.
A grain of sand will fit in the cave, but an elephant will not.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To conform to in size and shape.
examples: The small shirt doesn't fit me, so I'll buy the medium size.
If I lose a few kilos, the gorgeous wedding dress might fit me.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be of the right size and shape
examples: Even though in a way you let him freeze to death in the water, because the way I see it...I agree. Y'know, I think he actually could have fitted on that bit of door.There was plenty of room on the raft.I know. I know, I know.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive, with to) To make conform in size and shape.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To tailor; to change to the appropriate size.
examples: I had a suit fitted by the tailor.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be in agreement with.
examples: These definitions fit most of the usage.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To adjust.
examples: The regression program fit a line to the data.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To attach, especially when requiring exact positioning or sizing.
(transitive) To equip or supply.
examples: The chandler will fit us with provisions for a month.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make ready.
examples: I'm fitting the ship for a summer sail home.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To be seemly.
To be proper or becoming.
(intransitive) To be in harmony.
examples: The paint, the fabrics, the rugs all fit.

description: Unknown, possibly from Old English fitt (“song”), or from the sense of fitted to length. Compare Old Saxon *fittea (attested in the borrowed Latin vittea).

entries.meaning: (archaic) A section of a poem or ballad.
examples: Dr. Percy has written a long ballad in many fits.

description:
Unknown, possibly from Old English fitt (“conflict”).  Compare Cornish fit (“game match, bout”); or else, probably cognate with Italian fitta (“pain, especially sudden and stabbing pain”).
See more at Latin fīgere.

entries.meaning: A seizure or convulsion.
examples: My grandfather died after having a fit.

entries.meaning: (medicine) A sudden and vigorous appearance of a symptom over a short period of time.
A sudden outburst of emotion.
examples: Synonyms: blowout, hissy, tantrum, spell, moment
He had a laughing fit which lasted more than ten minutes.
She had a fit and threw all of his clothes out through the window.
He threw a fit when his car broke down.

entries.meaning: A sudden burst (of an activity).
examples: Synonyms: flurry, frenzy, paroxysm

verbs.description: fit (third-person singular simple present fits, present participle fitting, simple past and past participle fitted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, medicine) To suffer a fit.
examples: A spokesman said: "It is believed they (the dogs) got into the lake and drank from it. They came out and started fitting. Shortly after that three of them died and vets are attempting to resuscitate the other one."

description: Formed from fight on the model of bite:bit and light:lit.

entries.meaning: (African-American Vernacular, Southern US, dated) simple past tense and past participle of fight; fought.
examples: Joshua fit the battle of Jericho and the walls came tumbling down

entries.meaning: (informal) An outfit, a set of clothing.
examples: How do you like the fit?
